name: Flippers
description: Player-controlled paddles mounted near the bottom of the playfield, operated by buttons on the sides of the cabinet. Harry Mabs designed the first flipper mechanism for Gottlieb's *Humpty Dumpty* in 1947, and the invention transformed pinball from a game of aim into a game of reflexes and timing. Early machines used six flippers scattered across the playfield; by the early 1950s, the layout had consolidated to two flippers at the bottom — the configuration that became universal. Three-flipper and four-flipper layouts appear periodically when designers want additional shot options from the upper playfield.

name: Pop Bumpers
description: Active bumpers that kick the ball away on contact, powered by a solenoid triggered by a switch beneath the bumper cap. Also called jet bumpers or thumper bumpers. They generate the rapid-fire percussive sound that defines the pinball soundscape and add unpredictable energy to the ball's path. Most machines since the 1950s include a cluster of two or three pop bumpers in a region of the playfield where the ball ricochets chaotically between them, accumulating points with each hit.

name: Slingshots
description: Triangular kicker assemblies typically mounted just above the flippers on both sides of the playfield. When the ball strikes the rubberized face of the slingshot, a solenoid fires and kicks it back with force. Slingshots add speed and unpredictability to the lower playfield, often deflecting the ball into the outlanes or across to the opposite flipper. They became a standard feature of virtually every flipper game and are so universal that their absence on a machine is more notable than their presence.

name: Drop Targets
description: Flat rectangular targets mounted on spring-loaded mechanisms that retract below the playfield surface when struck by the ball. Typically arranged in banks of three, four, or five, they present the player with a completion challenge: knock down the entire bank to score a bonus or advance a game objective, then watch them reset for another round. Gottlieb pioneered drop targets in the early 1960s, and they became one of the most versatile and widely used playfield mechanisms in pinball design, appearing in electromechanical and solid-state machines alike.

name: Standup Targets
description: Fixed vertical targets that register a hit when struck by the ball but remain in place — they don't drop, retract, or move. The simplest form of scoring target on the playfield, standup targets are typically flat plastic or metal plates mounted on leaf switches, arranged individually or in groups to spell words, complete sequences, or guard high-value areas. They require less mechanism than drop targets and can be placed almost anywhere on the playfield, making them the workhorse target of pinball design.

name: Spinners
description: Rotating metal gates mounted in a lane that spin freely when the ball passes through, scoring points on each revolution. A hard, fast shot sends the spinner whirling through dozens of rotations, racking up points with a satisfying metallic whir. Spinners reward shot power rather than precision and are typically placed at the entrance to orbits or upper playfield lanes where a strong shot is required to reach them. They were a staple of both EM and early solid-state designs, and they remain a popular feature in modern games.

name: Ramps
description: Elevated tracks that carry the ball up and over portions of the playfield, returning it via wireforms or molded plastic guides. Ramps transformed playfield design beginning in the early 1980s, adding a vertical dimension to a game that had been essentially flat. A successful ramp shot — the ball climbing the incline with just enough speed to crest the top and glide down the return — is one of pinball's most satisfying moments. Ramps enabled loop shots, combo sequences, and the complex multi-shot rule sets that defined the dot-matrix era.

name: Multiball
description: A game state in which two or more balls are in play simultaneously, typically triggered by locking balls in designated features and then releasing them all at once. Multiball is the climactic event in most modern pinball designs — the moment when scoring multipliers peak, the music intensifies, and the player's ability to track and control multiple balls determines whether the round produces a massive score or a rapid drain. Williams' *Firepower* (1980) is credited as the first machine to feature multiball as a designed gameplay objective, and the mechanic has been central to pinball game design ever since.

name: Captive Ball
description: A ball permanently trapped behind a target or within a channel on the playfield, struck indirectly by the player's ball to register hits or advance scoring. The captive ball never drains — it lives in its enclosure for the life of the machine, absorbing impacts and transferring momentum to switches behind it. The mechanism creates a distinctive heavy, satisfying hit feel unlike any other target on the playfield. Captive balls appear in hundreds of machines across the solid-state and DMD eras, often positioned as a high-value repeated shot.

name: Kick-Out Holes
description: Holes in the playfield that capture the ball and then eject it back into play via a solenoid-powered kicker. Also called saucers, scoops, or eject holes depending on their orientation and mechanism. The ball disappears below the playfield surface — a moment of pause in the action — before being launched back out, often to a specific location that sets up the next shot. Kick-out holes serve as collection points for mode starts, locks, and awards, and their placement fundamentally shapes the flow of a playfield design.

name: Gobble Holes
description: Holes in the playfield that swallow the ball and end it — no eject, no return. The ball drops through and is gone, awarding its score but costing the player that ball of play. Gobble holes were a defining feature of pre-flipper and early flipper-era machines, where the entire playfield was a landscape of risk: every hole was a potential ending. As flippers gave players more control and game designs shifted toward keeping the ball in play longer, gobble holes largely disappeared from mainstream pinball, surviving primarily in novelty games and as historical curiosities.

name: Kickback
description: A solenoid-powered mechanism in the outlane that fires the ball back onto the playfield instead of allowing it to drain. The kickback is a second chance — earned by completing a target sequence or hitting a specific shot — that rescues the ball from what would otherwise be an unrecoverable drain. Typically installed in the left outlane, kickbacks must usually be re-earned after each use. The feature adds a strategic layer: players must decide whether to prioritize re-lighting the kickback or pursuing higher-scoring objectives elsewhere on the playfield.

name: Magna-Save
description: A patented Williams mechanism that uses an electromagnet beneath the playfield to grab and hold a steel ball as it rolls toward the outlane. The player activates the magnet by pressing a dedicated button — separate from the flipper buttons — at precisely the right moment. If the timing is correct, the ball sticks to the playfield surface long enough for gravity to pull it back toward the flippers. Magna-Save was introduced on *Black Knight* in 1980 and appeared on a handful of subsequent Williams titles. It remains one of pinball's most dramatic save mechanics: a physical intervention that feels like cheating the laws of physics.

name: Ball Save
description: A timed grace period at the beginning of each ball — or after certain events — during which a drained ball is automatically returned to the plunger lane for another try. Ball save is the modern, software-controlled descendant of the mechanical kickback: invisible, automatic, and temporary. It protects players against the frustration of a drain on the first shot and ensures that every ball gets a fair chance to reach the flippers. The feature became standard on WPC-era machines in the early 1990s and is now virtually universal on new titles.

name: Skill Shot
description: A scoring opportunity presented at the moment the ball is launched into play, rewarding the player for a precise plunge. The simplest skill shots require hitting a specific target or lane with the initial plunge; more elaborate versions involve timing the plunge to hit a moving light or choosing between multiple targets at different power levels. The skill shot transforms the plunge — historically a throwaway moment — into a meaningful decision point at the start of every ball. Some machines offer a super skill shot that requires a soft plunge followed by an immediate flipper shot.

name: Multi-Level Playfield
description: A playfield design incorporating two or more distinct playing levels stacked vertically, each with its own features, targets, and sometimes its own set of flippers. Williams' *Black Knight* (1980) introduced the concept with an upper playfield accessible via a ramp, and the design became a hallmark of ambitious games that wanted to pack more features into a standard-width cabinet. Multi-level playfields add physical depth and shot variety, creating distinct zones of play that the ball transitions between — though they also increase manufacturing complexity and can make the lower playfield feel cramped.

name: Magnets
description: Electromagnets mounted beneath the playfield surface that can grab, slow, deflect, or redirect the ball during play. Unlike Magna-Save, which is player-activated, playfield magnets are typically software-controlled — the game decides when to energize them, creating unpredictable ball movement that no amount of player skill can fully anticipate. Williams' *Twilight Zone* (1993) used magnets to spectacular effect, and the mechanism has since become a standard tool in the designer's kit for creating moments of surprise, challenge, and controlled chaos.

name: Replay
description: A free game awarded to the player for exceeding a score threshold, completing a specific in-game objective, or winning a match at the end of the game. The replay is the coin-operated amusement industry's fundamental reward: play well enough and you earn another game without inserting another coin. Replay thresholds could be set by the operator to control how frequently free games were awarded, balancing player satisfaction against revenue. In jurisdictions where replays were legally classified as gambling, manufacturers offered add-a-ball as an alternative reward system.

name: Add-a-Ball
description: An alternative reward system in which the player earns an additional ball of play rather than a free game. Add-a-ball emerged as a response to local regulations that classified replay awards as gambling: if the machine never awarded a free game, it could not be considered a gambling device. The distinction was legally significant — it determined whether a machine could be placed on location in a given jurisdiction. Machines configured for add-a-ball play typically displayed different artwork and messaging to make the distinction clear to both players and regulators.

name: Head-to-Head
description: A game configuration in which two players compete simultaneously on the same machine, each controlling their own set of flippers on opposite ends of the playfield. Head-to-head machines are rare — the standard pinball format is turn-based, with players alternating balls on a single playfield. True simultaneous head-to-head play requires a symmetrical or dual playfield design and a scoring system that can track two players in real time. The format has appeared periodically as a novelty, most notably in machines designed specifically for competitive or tournament play.
